article.inleiding: 1. INTRODUCTION Danish law on agricultural tenancy is quite different from other European countries - e.g. The Netherlands.1 Thus, in The Netherlands you find a detailed legislation - 'de Pachtwet' - dealing with matters of both private and public law, restricting the freedom of the landlord and the tenant. In Denmark - on the other hand - the freedom of the parties to decide the content of their agreements is the dominating principle in agricultural law. So, The Danish act on Farms2 lays out only 2 (two) sections on agricultural tenancy. But, not only the intensity of the legislation is different. It is very interesting to notice that the use of agricultural tenancy has decreased in The Netherlands for the last 30 years or more, while it has increased - slowly but constantly - in Denmark.3 The purpose of this article is to give a short survey of Danish law, describing some of the advantages and disadvantages of the very liberal legislation at a time when the passing of amendments to 'de Pachtwet' is considered in The Netherlands.
article.content: 2. THE ACT ON FARMS AND IT'S SCOPE The Act on Farms' section 11 lays out rules for letting on lease an entire farm. Section 12 concerns only parts of a farm. The purpose of the sections is to limit the use of agricultural tenancy. Thus, the act lays out a maximum duration of 30 years for all leases.4 This limitation is closely connected with the rules applying to the buying of farm land in Denmark and with the agricultural policy of The Danish Government: The farm land is considered as a limited resource of nature and as such it should be used for agricultural purposes in the best possible way, cultivated by fulltime employed and well-educated farmers. See section 1, subsections 1 and 2 in The Act on Farms. In accordance with this policy the buying of farm land is restricted: The buyer has to fulfil some educational conditions, he has to take up permanent residence on the farm within 6 months from the day of purchase and he is not allowed to buy if he and/or his wife and children younger than 18 years of age own another farm or a part of a farm - see The Act on Farms' section 16, subsection 1. However, some exemptions are given in subsection 3. The purpose of section 16 is to reserve the use of the farm land for professional farmers with an agricultural education and to prevent townsmen from buying and using the land for recreation or for hobby farming. The educational conditions also assure an appropriate cultivation of the land5. The condition of permanent residence prevents townsmen from buying farm land if they do not want to live in the country-side. The owner living in the towns could lead to a damaging use of the land. Furthermore, there is a risk of the land being bought by investors and let on lease to farmers for a high rent.6 Investments are also controlled by the limitation in the number of farms the buyer and his family are allowed to own. The purpose of limiting the use of tenancy, is first of all to prevent the parties getting round the above mentioned rules e.g. by letting the land on lease for many years. Thus, a 50 year irrevocable lease would be almost the same as if the tenant owned the land. So, it is necessary that the rules on purchase and tenancy are co-ordinated. Below is given a survey of the rules on tenancy and their connection with the rules on purchase. If a person wants to lease an entire farm he must fulfil the conditions laid out by The Act on Farms' Section 11, subsection 1, meaning that the tenant must: 1) be 18 years or older. If he is younger he needs the permission of his parents or his legal guardian; 2) be a citizen in one of the member states of the EEC; 3) fulfil certain educational conditions if the area of the land let on lease is larger than 30 hectares.7 In this way the educational conditions correspond with those in section 16 and prevents a buyer getting round the conditions by a long term lease. If the land let on lease is smaller than 30 hectares, but the total amount of land cultivated by the tenant ex ceeds 30 hectares, he must fulfil the educational conditions as well; 4) take up permanent residence on the farm that he leases or on his own farm, if it is not situated more than 10 kilometres away from the leased land. This is in order to pre vent townsmen from leasing farm land, using it for recreative purposes or hobby farming; 5) not run more than 5 farms or parts of farms at the same time. The purpose of this condition is to avoid a few persons getting all the farm land at their disposal by making up numerous leases. Some further requirements are laid out by section 11, subsection 3: Leases concerning an entire farm must be in writing - verbal agreements are illegal. In the lease must be given information on the duration, on the terms of notice and on the rent agreed on by the parties. This is supposed to make leases clear and comprehensible, which is especially important when concerning an entire farm because large amounts of money are involved. If one or more of these conditions are not fulfilled the agreement is illegal and both the landlord and the tenant could be fined (see section 33) unless an exemption is given by the Minister of Agriculture. However, the lease can not be declared null and void. Section 12 in The Act on Farms concerning parts of a farm is less restrictive than section 11. The most important part (subsection 1, no. 1) - concerning larger parts of land with or without buildings - repeats some of the conditions laid out by section 11. Thus, the tenant has to fulfil the conditions mentioned above under number 1, 2, 4 and 5. However, the conditions in section 11, subsection 3 are not repeated. This means that a lease concerning only a part of a farm, does not have to be in writing and the parties do not have to give any information on the duration, on the terms of notice or on the agreed rent. The practical problems caused by these differences are discussed below. If the tenant does not fulfil the conditions, the consequences are the same as apply to section 11. These conditions are the only ones laid out by The Act on Farms. So, the parties are free to make agreements on all other subjects e.g. the minimum duration of the lease, what rent to pay etc., as long as the lease is not against other parts of the legislation or the public order. The Act on Farms does not grant the parties any special rights like e.g. a right of prolongation or a right of economic compensation for improvements made on the farm by the tenant. 3. ADVANTAGES AND DISADVANTAGES OF A LIBERAL TENANCY LEGISLATION Like almost any legislation, The Act on Farms both causes and solves problems. Below is given a description of some of the main advantages and disadvantages of The Act. 3.7. Advantages The advantages of the liberal legislation are quite obvious: It causes an increase in the use of agricultural tenancy. Even though the purpose of The Act on Farms is to limit the use of tenancy, the increase must be considered as an advantage. After all it is not the purpose of the act to abolish all use of tenancy. The increase produces several advantages. First of all tenancy makes it possible for a farmer to obtain the best possible agricultural structure. If a farm is too small for a certain type of farming, it is possible to make it larger by leasing more land. Buying more land is expensive and not always possible. Therefore, an increase in the use of tenancy could indicate an improvement of the agricultural structure in Denmark. Furthermore, tenancy makes it possible for a farmer to fulfil special demands set up by the legislation for his production. E.g. the amounts of milk and manure that the farmer is allowed to produce - without having to pay extra taxes - are proportional to the size of his farm. So, if a farmer wants to expand his farm in order to avoid extra taxes or simply to obtain the economic advantages of large-scale fanning, it is convenient - and in Denmark rather inexpensive - to do so by leasing the land. On the other hand a restrictive legislation would limit the farmers' chances of adapting their farms to the requirements of the legislation and/or the chances of extending and improving the production. Finally, agricultural tenancy makes it easier for young farmers to start their own agricultural production. To buy land requires a lot of money, which can be difficult to raise for a young farmer. It is much easier to raise money to pay the rent. So, the Danish legislation has obvious advantages. But, it must be pointed out that The Act on Farms is not the only reason for the increase in the use of tenancy. E.g. the EEC legislation on milk forces many farmers to lease land if they want to expand their production of milk. A lot of different factors determine the use of tenancy - The Act on Farms only being one of them. 3.2. Disadvantages However, the liberal legislation causes problems as well. In fact the extended freedom of the parties means that many problems remain unsolved, either because the parties do not consider every detail when making the lease or because the legislation gives no solution to specific problems. Below is given a description of three of the major disadvantages of the liberal legislation. These are not the only problems; but to cover them all is impossible on these few pages. The form of the lease As mentioned above, leases concerning a part of a farm could be verbal. In practice this causes problems for the administrative authorities and for the parties. For the supervision on leases carried out by the administrative authorities it is of major importance, that as many leases as possible are in writing. If any authority finds out about a verbal agreement it would be almost impossible to decide whether it complies with the Act or not. It would be very easy for the parties - if they wanted to get round the Act - to inform the authorities of an agreement with a legal content and then in practice act against The Act on Farms. Of course, an illegal arrangement only exists as long as the parties agree. If one of the parties - e.g. the tenant - no longer accepts the illegal terms, he could turn to the authorities, to get them changed. But in Denmark both parties could be fined if they have agreed on an illegal lease (see section 33 in The Act on Farms). So, there has to be a fairly good reason for one of them turning to the authorities. Furthermore, the pressure from neighbours and the fear of social isolation would often prevent an unsatisfied tenant from doing so. The supervision is also insufficient because the parties are not obliged to notify any public authority about their agreement or to register the lease in The Land Registry. In this way, the authorities are normally not informed when farm land is let on lease. This makes the supervision quite restrained and accidental. Very often it is only carried out if the authorities come across a lease for some special reason: By accident or if the tenant wants to register the lease in The Land Registry. 8 A verbal lease is not very convenient for the parties either. It is informal and unclear. This means that the risk of unexpected problems occurring is considerable and the parties often have different views about what was originally agreed on. Disagreements about even minor problems - which could have been solved in a single line in a written lease - can easily - and do often - lead to the end of the tenancy agreement, causing heavy damage to either one or both of the parties. Furthermore, the inconsequent sections in the act lead to some quite irrational results. The size of the area which can be let on lease as a part of a farm is not limited by The Act on Farms section 12. E.g. all the land without the buildings could legally be let on lease as a part of a farm. Therefore very large areas can be let on lease by an informal, verbal agreement involving large amounts of money. Furthermore, it is possible for the parties to make two different verbal agreements: One concerning the land and another concerning the buildings. Both agreements are only concerning a part of a farm. This would of course be an attempt to get round The Act on Farms' section 12 because the leases actually concern an entire farm. But it would be very difficult for the authorities to provide sufficient evidence for the existence of both agreements and to prove that they are illegal. In this way the parties could get round the conditions in section 11. So, it is possible to make agreements on very similar objects where one of the agreements has to be in writing while the other one could be verbal. It is difficult to understand how an insignificant difference of fact in some cases can be the reason for the significant difference laid out by the Act. The purposes of the demand of written leases on entire farms, are to prevent disagreements between the parties, to create clear leases and to prevent loss of money for the parties. The same purposes seem to apply quite well to leases concerning (large) parts of farms as well. But, why are the conditions different then? In practice verbal leases appear frequently. Whether they are legal or not, they cause problems for the parties and the authorities.9 If verbal tenancy agreements were banned, the problems would be minimized. Furthermore, the authorities ought to be given better possibilities to perform the supervision of leases. Today it is too easy to get round the Act. (Or section 11 and 12 should be totally repealed since they make no sense if the supervision is too insufficient.) Maintenance of the farm let on lease The subject most often causing problems in Denmark is probably the maintenance of the farm. Who is to be in charge of and to pay for repairs etc.? In despite of the fact that the question arises in relation to many leases, Danish law does not deal with it like e.g. 'de Pachtwet', ยง 6. Of course the problem is of a limited nature if the parties themselves solve it in the lease. That happens, but a very large percentage of the leases makes only this division: 'The tenant is in charge of and pays for the usual maintenance of the soil and the buildings while the landlord is obliged to reconstruct the buildings in case they burn down. The landlord alone decides the position of the new buildings'. Often the obligation of the landlord is limited even more, so that he only has to reconstruct the buildings if he finds it appropriate - without any regard to the tenant's needs. Reading this agreement, it seems as if the obligations of the tenant are almost unlimited. The words 'usual maintenance' could cover any form of repair etc. except the reconstruction of buildings burned down. However, in practice the duties are often shared by the parties to a considerable degree. But it might be very difficult to decide which one of the parties is to pay for the repair of a specific damage if they do not agree and a stipulation like the one mentioned above is the only means of interpretation. Danish courts have been dealing with some of the problems, at least in the first half of this century. It seems as if they have tried to evolve some general principles - but only five decisions have been published - the latest in 1941. So, the work is not at all completed and the leases dealt with in the five decisions are in some ways old-fashioned compared to modern leases. Apparently the courts have tried to split up the maintenance into two groups: The usual and the extraordinary forms of maintenance. This division is very similar to the one used in most modern leases but the courts give a little more explicit formulation of what is meant by 'usual maintenance': The tenant has to keep the farm in good condition during the entire period of leasing. In order to do so, the tenant has to carry out all necessary repairs and mending, e.g. paint the buildings, fertilize the soil and spray with herbicides when necessary. In other words, all the daily work which has to be done in order to keep the farm in a good condition is 'usual maintenance' and must be carried out and/or paid for by the tenant. In this way there are some similarities between Danish case law and art. 25 in 'de Pachtwet'. The lower limit of the usual maintenance seems to be the deteriorations of the farm caused by the ravages of time and which occur at all farms whether they are let on lease or not. But 'the ravages of time' is very difficult to define and only very few hints have been given by the courts. The upper limit is even more diffuse because the courts in only one case have decided on the extraordinary forms of maintenance. Thus, in a decision from 1907, it was decided that a landlord had to pay for the reconstruction of a building which burned down after being struck by lightning. The court found that the damages were so extraordinary and had nothing to do with the tenant keeping the farm in good condition that they were at the risk of the landlord. But, presumably the duties of the landlord go beyond the repair of damages caused by nature. However, the only certain conclusion is that the smallest and the largest repairs have to be paid by the landlord. Repairs in between are to be paid by the tenant. But the limits are very diffuse and doubt easily and often occurs. Difficult problems arise because of the missing legislation and the sparse case law. This happens e.g. in relation to the maintenance of the drainpipes. Normally, the tenant has to pay for the repair of one or two pipes and the landlord has to pay if a total replacement of the drainpipes is needed because this is extraordinary maintenance. But what happens if e.g. 1/3 of the pipes needs to be renewed? In Danish law there is no plain answer to this question. And because most disputes between parties are settled by arbitration no new case law turns up, since the arbitration awards are not public like the court decisions. Therefore, the Danish law is actually not developing at all in this field; it is stuck where it was more than 50 years ago. So, the answer is very much depending on the circumstances. Finally, some landlords try to take advantage of the tenant by imposing unreasonable burdens of maintenance on him, knowing that the sparse legislation does not prevent it. Thus, leases occur, which impose almost every kind of maintenance on the tenant. The costs of this can be difficult to foresee because a damage often happens very sudden, causing heavy economic strain to the tenant. Of course, it is very difficult to deal with all the different types of maintenance of a farm in a single act. But it seems to be possible - and a good idea as well - to enact some statutes dealing with the most common situations. In this way problems could be reduced to a minimum of unusual situations only occurring rarely. E.g. statutes on the maintenance of drainpipes and buildings would be a good idea, because these often cause problems. The tenant's right to claim prolongation of the lease. A very important part of 'de Pachtwet' is ยง 7 which lays out rules on the prolongation of the lease. Similar rules are also known in other European countries. But in Danish law they do not exist. Furthermore, the rules seem quite strange because of the important role the freedom of the parties is playing in Danish agricultural law. A right for the tenant to claim prolongation without the landlord having agreed does not fit in with this freedom. The fact that rules on prolongation are unfamiliar to Danish law, it does not necessarily mean that there is no need for such rules at all. The reasons for the right of prolongation are combinations of social and economic considerations. The tenant's social and economic conditions are often depending on the tenancy. If the lease ends, the tenant and his family may have to leave their house and home and give up their only source of income causing heavy economic and social losses. Of course these considerations apply in Denmark as well, even though no legislation has been enacted. If the tenant has a right to claim prolongation, he has a longer respite to adjust his finances and his private life to the end of the lease. Moreover, the average duration of a lease in Denmark is 5 years. In this short period of time it is not always possible to write off major investments made in the farm. Therefore a tenant sometimes might need a longer duration than originally agreed on. Since there is no right for the tenant to claim prolongation, he is very dependent on the attitude of the landlord towards a continuation or a renewal of the lease. A right of prolongation restricts the possibilities of the landlord putting pressure on the tenant. If the tenant needs a prolongation, he is more willing to accept unfair conditions demanded by the landlord for the new period of leasing because it is normally impossible to find another farm to lease (or buy) with a short notice. If the tenant - on the other hand - has a right of prolongation the landlord can not put the same pressure on him. But, in practice the problems seem to be rather small. One of the reasons is perhaps that Danish tenants plan their farming in another way than e.g. Dutch farmers. Danish farmers know that a prolongation can not be expected. Therefore they have to try to make the period of leasing long enough from the start. Then the need of prolongation only occurs quite rarely. But of course it is impossible to take everything into consideration when planning the lease. So, too short leases do occur. Furthermore, very few tenants inhabit the farm or the part of the farm which they lease.10 And very few farmers base their production entirely on land let on lease by a third party; most tenants own some land as well. This means that the social effect on the tenant and his family caused by the end of the lease is limited because only few tenants have to leave their homes with a short notice. So, the need of a social protection of the tenant is rather modest. Tenants who inhabit their own farm and only lease some additional land are often - but not always - able to manage the end of the lease with limited economical losses because they can continue there production on their own land. However, tenants who actually get in trouble are not at all protected by the legislation. Not even The Danish Act on Rent applies to agricultural tenancy. Therefore, a farmer, who inhabits the buildings of a farm let on lease, is less protected than if he was renting a flat. In fact section 12, subsection 3 in The Act on Farms overrules the protection given to the lessee by The Act on Rent. Thus, the latter does not apply to the buildings on a farm if the landlord or people working at the farm need the buildings to live in. So, in some - few - cases the protection of the tenant might be inadequate and perhaps a limited right to claim prolongation could solve some of the problems. But, it is very important to weigh the interests of the landlord in proportion to the interests of the tenant before and when enacting such legislation. Too restrictive rules, limiting the freedom of the landlord, could easily lead to higher rents because he would want something in return for the restricted freedom. Some owners might even choose not to let their land on lease if they could not be certain of the lease ending at the time agreed on. Both reactions would cause a decrease in the use of tenancy; the size of it depending on how restrictive the legislation is. Taken into consideration the experiences learned in other countries, the first steps towards a legislation in Denmark must be made with care and consideration. It is very likely that many landlords would react very strongly to even minor attempts to limit their freedom. It is difficult to estimate the effect of a right of prolongation, but it must be taken seriously into consideration that the liberal agricultural legislation and the principle of freedom for the parties goes back more than 200 years. Sudden restrictions could cause devastating damages to the tenancy market. So, compared with the probably small achievements obtained by a legislation, the damages could very well turn out to be too heavy. The result could be even worse, if the right to claim prolongation is combined with a right for the tenant to apply for the replacement of himself with a member of his family. 'De Pachtwet' art. 49 lays out such a right for the tenant called: 'pachtoverneming'. Thus, under Dutch law it is possible for a tenant, who himself can not claim prolongation of the lease - e.g. because he is too old (art. 38a) - to turn to 'de pachtkamer' according to art. 49 and apply for himself being substituted by e.g. his son or wife. Then the new tenant (i.e. the son or wife) can claim prolongation11. This system gives the landlord very few chances to end a lease. In Denmark the tenant can only be replaced by another if the landlord agrees. This seems to cause very few - if any - problems. If there is a need for a replacement of the tenant, the landlord would often allow it (at least for the current leasing period) and fairly often the lease gives the tenant such a right. So, the missing legislation on the subject is causing almost no problems. Instead serious problems could occur, if a general right of replacement - combined with a right of prolongation - was enacted. Then probably very few owners of farm land would let it on lease, being afraid of a very long and unpredictable duration. There seems to be no reason at all for enacting such rules in Denmark! 4. CONCLUSION Taken the above mentioned disadvantages into consideration the Danish legislation on agricultural tenancy must be recognized as too liberal. The legislation is unable to prevent the occurrence and solution of certain important problems. So, there is a need for passing an amendment. But - as it has already been pointed out - it is important that this is prepared with most care and consideration - taking the interests of both parties into account - in order to avoid a sudden major decrease in the use of tenancy. This especially applies to rules on prolongation because almost any advantage obtained by the tenant would cause a corresponding or even larger disadvantage for the landlord. It is very difficult to find the balance between the parties' interest. Perhaps the landlord could be given some compensation for a right of prolongation - e.g. a higher rent - so that the tenant would be paying for the social and economic security that he gets. Thus, establishing a sort of insurance for the tenant. However, rules on prolongation should only apply to those persons who really need the protection: Tenants who live at the farm that they rent and tenants who have made large investments in the farm. An intervention by the legislator concerning other subjects would presumably cause less problems. E.g. some general statutes on the maintenance of the farm would be to the benefit of both landlords and tenants because it would make clear their rights and obligations. This applies to more consequent statutes on the form and the content of the lease as well. But, still the main principle in Danish agricultural law is - and will continue to be - the freedom of agreement; and good reasons must be given before restricting this freedom.
